courseTitle: Faster Plop, Plop, Fizz, Fizz: A Scientific Method Investigation

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>scientific method</button> is an approach to answering a question. <button class='glossary-text'>Science</button> is an evidence-based discipline that attempts to build a better understanding of the natural world and how it works. In this exercise, the scientific method is used to investigate the rate at which effervescent tablets dissolve in water and to identify the factors that affect this rate. After an initial experiment, a question will be developed, and the scientific method will be applied to answer it.

text: Formulate a <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button> that can be tested empirically, i.e., based on observation.
Understand independent, dependent, and <button class='glossary-text'>controlled variables</button> and how to apply them in designing an experiment.
Apply key principles of the <button class='glossary-text'>scientific method</button> in designing an experiment to answer a question.
Analyze data generated by the experiment to determine whether it supports or refutes the hypothesis.

pageData.text: Have you ever made the observation that your phone is not turning on? The black screen stares at you no matter what you do. You may ask yourself the question, “why is my phone not working?” You guess that maybe you forgot to charge your phone; however, you confirm the charger is plugged into the phone. Your guess then evolves based on this data: maybe the charging plug has been pulled out of the wall outlet. After tracing the cable back to the wall, you find it is indeed unplugged. You plug the charging cord back into the wall and the result is the phone is now charging as shown by the phone’s battery icon. You have just worked your way through the .The ability to make an observation and ask a question about that observation is paramount to the scientific method. But finding an answer to that question is where the scientific method is most impactful. Imagine observing your phone not working and wondering why, then walking away without a solution. While observation and curiosity are important first steps in , the journey to finding answers is equally as valuable.

pageData.desc: A person holding a smartphone with a blank screen.
pageData.altText: A person holding a smartphone with a blank screen.

pageData.text: In our day-to-day experience, we all make observations about how the world works. In the fall, the leaves on trees change color. In the springtime, pansies are one of the first flowers to bloom. Sometimes these observations stimulate our curiosity. Why are pansies one of the first flowers to bloom each year? What characteristics of pansies are responsible for their early blooming? Are there ways that pansies can be pushed to bloom even earlier?

The goal of scientific research is to try to understand these phenomena at a deeper level by asking questions. <button class='glossary-text'>Science</button> is an evidence-based discipline that attempts to build a better understanding of the natural world and how it works. One of the primary tools of scientific research is the use of the <button class='glossary-text'>scientific method</button> to answer specific questions.

The scientific method involves doing experiments and making observations to answer a question of interest. The question generally arises from an observation such as “Why do leaves change color?” or “Why are pansies one of the first flowers to bloom each year?” or “Why do apples turn brown after they are cut?”

While there are many approaches to answering a question, the scientific method takes a distinctive approach. First, the question must be testable. A testable question is one for which empirical, or measurable, data can be collected to answer the question or provide insight. Another important component of testability is reproducibility. The empirical or measurable data must always yield the same results under identical conditions.

pageData.question: Which of the following is an example of a testable question?

options.text: Do tomato plants grow better in full sun?
How do tomato plants grow?
Are tomato plants the best plant?
Do tomatoes taste better than potatoes?
Do red tomatoes taste better than green tomatoes?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Testable questions are ones from which a researcher can collect measurable data in order to answer the question. A testable question will lead to the design of an experiment that is also reproducible, meaning the data are consistent if repeated under the exact same conditions.

pageData.question: Which of the following is an example of a testable question?

options.text: What is the effect of exercise on urine pH?
At what pH does water taste best?
Why is well water harder than spring water?
Where does tap water come from?
How do pH test strips work?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Testable questions are ones from which a researcher can collect measurable data in order to answer the question. A testable question will lead to the design of an experiment that is also reproducible, meaning the data are consistent if repeated under the exact same conditions.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Testable questions are questions for which measurable data can be collected. Think about whether you can design and conduct an experiment centered around your question. Can you change one thing “A” and then measure its effect on another thing “B”? For example, you can change the amount of sunlight tomato plants receive and then measure the height or number of fruits produced by those plants. However, you cannot measure something subjective, like color. Testable questions are also reproducible, so the data must be consistent if repeated under the exact same conditions. Repeating the full-sun experiment with tomato plants in a different city should yield comparable results to the original experiment.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Testable questions are questions for which measurable data can be collected. Think about whether you can design and conduct an experiment centered around your question. Can you change one thing “A” and then measure its effect on another thing “B”? For example, you can change the amount of sunlight tomato plants receive and then measure the height or number of fruits produced by those plants. However, you cannot measure something subjective, like color. Testable questions are also reproducible, so the data must be consistent if repeated under the exact same conditions. Repeating the full-sun experiment with tomato plants in a different city should yield comparable results to the original experiment.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>scientific method</button> can be used either to investigate an observed phenomenon or to design an experiment to test a <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button>. The investigator integrates previous knowledge in developing the hypothesis, and acquires new knowledge in the process of testing the hypothesis. The new knowledge gained can either support or refute the hypothesis. However, if the data collected are inconsistent with previous findings, and if these new observations or data are reliably reproduced by other investigators, the existing broad scientific understanding or theory may have to be revised and potentially discarded. <button class='glossary-text'>Science</button> has a built-in mechanism for self-correction, as justified by new evidence, to more accurately reflect reality.
The overall process followed in the scientific method is represented below in Figure 1.

Some people mistakenly believe that humans know everything there is to know about nature and natural processes, and that this knowledge is all-encompassing. Nothing could be further from the truth! In scientific research, questions are answered based on experimental evidence; however, new questions are also raised. This is true in all branches of natural science. Scientists will continue to seek answers to new questions and to develop technologies to address both new questions and those that might have been unanswerable with earlier technologies.

Factors relevant to the question being asked are called <button class='glossary-text'>variables</button>. In designing a scientific experiment, only one factor, or variable, is changed at a given time. There are three different kinds of variables involved in an experiment. The <button class='glossary-text'>independent variable</button> is the factor hypothesized to produce the effect under investigation. This variable can be measured and is often controlled by the investigator. Some common independent variables are time, temperature, concentration, pH, and pressure.

<button class='glossary-text'>Dependent variables</button> are also measurable, but their values are dependent on the <button class='glossary-text'>independent variables</button>; i.e., the behavior of the dependent variable is based on the status of the independent variable. An easy way to think about the independent and dependent variables is the following statement, “If I change the independent variable from X to Y, what will happen to the dependent variable?” A scientist will control the rate of change of the independent variable and observe the resulting change in the dependent variable.

The third type of variable is a <button class='glossary-text'>controlled variable</button>. Controlled variables are all other, nonindependent and nondependent variables, and they should remain unchanged while the independent variable is manipulated and the effect on the dependent variable is measured or observed.

pageData.question: You are conducting an experiment to answer the question “how does fertilizer affect tomato plant growth?” Which is the independent variable?

options.text: the amount of fertilizer used on each plant
the temperature in the room during the experiment
the size of the tomatoes produced by the plants
the number of leaves on the tomato plants
the number of tomatoes produced by the plants

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The independent variable is the component of an experiment that the researcher changes in order to affect the dependent variable.

pageData.question: You are conducting an experiment to answer the question “how does saltwater concentration affect the growth of brine shrimp?” What is the dependent variable?

options.text: the volume of water in each tank
the water temperature in each tank
the number of brine shrimp in each tank
the brand of salt used to salinize the water in each tank
the salinity of the water in each tank

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The dependent variable is how the effect of the independent variable is measured. After changing the concentration of salt (salinity) in each brine shrimp tank, the researcher can observe the number of brine shrimp in each tank and answer the question being tested.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An independent variable is the component of an experiment that the researcher changes. By changing thing “A” (the independent variable), and then measuring its effect on thing “B” (the dependent variable), the researcher will have data and insight to answer the question being tested. The relationship between the independent and dependent variables is often apparent when the testable question is formulated as “how does A affect B?”

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An independent variable is the component of an experiment that the researcher changes. By changing thing “A” (the independent variable), and then measuring its effect on thing “B” (the dependent variable), the researcher will have data and insight to answer the question being tested. The relationship between the independent and dependent variables is often apparent when the testable question is formulated as “how does A affect B?”

pageData.text: A real-world example of a phenomenon that an environmental scientist may investigate is the impact of algal blooms on a specific species of fish. Environmental scientists know, based on previous research, that algal blooms decrease the oxygen level in the water. The testable <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button> that may be proposed is “Lower oxygen levels in water cause increased heart rate in fish.” A hypothesis is an educated assumption or prediction of what one expects to observe, or the predicted results of an experiment. The scientist hypothesizes that, at lower oxygen levels in the water, the heart rate of the fish would increase. If true, this might explain the mechanism that leads to stress or death in the fish population associated with algal blooms.

In the experiment, the oxygen level (<button class='glossary-text'>independent variable</button>) can be manipulated and the resulting heart rate of the fish (dependent variable) can be measured. In order to make this study meaningful and reproducible, all other (controlled) <button class='glossary-text'>variables</button> must remain constant. For example, if the oxygen level and temperature were simultaneously manipulated, the scientist would not know which variable led to the change in the heart rate. Some examples of <button class='glossary-text'>controlled variables</button> in this experiment include water temperature, water pH, and light level. The experimental design must be able to accommodate these different kinds of variables so that all relevant controlled variables are held constant while the independent and <button class='glossary-text'>dependent variables</button> are manipulated and measured, respectively.

When the experiment is run and repeated to assess reproducibility, the hypothesis can be supported or not supported. More questions will likely be generated based on the analysis of the experimental data. Subsequent experiments will ask new questions and the hypothesis will be refined until an understanding is achieved of whether reduced oxygen level is associated with increased heart rate in fish and, ultimately, of the impact on fish of all factors associated with an algal bloom.

In this lab activity, the <button class='glossary-text'>scientific method</button> will be used to answer a much simpler question: “How fast does an Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet dissolve in water at different temperatures?” A <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button> will be developed and tested. The experiment will then be repeated to determine whether the result is reproducible. After the first activity, a second hypothesis will be developed for another variable. A test protocol will be developed and the second hypothesis will be tested.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. You will start Activity 1 by preparing three water baths with different temperatures. You will prepare the Alka-Seltzer® tablets and record the time in which a tablet dissolves in each bath. After you have completed all three trials, you will calculate the average time and temperature for each bath type. In Activity 2, you develop five questions and hypotheses about how different variables will impact the rate at which Alka-Seltzer® tablets dissolve. You will design and perform the experiments. After you gather the data, you will evaluate your results and your hypotheses.

Safety goggles should be worn during this investigation. There are no additional safety concerns.

Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including use of appropriate personal protective equipment described in the Safety and Procedure sections.The Alka-Seltzer® in this kit is not for human consumption. The packages have not been kept in a food-grade facility and may be contaminated. Consider the tablet a laboratory chemical and not an over-the-counter pharmaceutical. Alka-Seltzer® contains aspirin and should be kept out of reach of children and pets.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area and all glassware with soap and water after completing the investigation.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of these best describes the steps of the scientific method in order?

options.text: observation, question, hypothesis, experiment, data analysis, hypothesis evaluation
data analysis, hypothesis, experiment, observation, question, hypothesis evaluation
question, observation, experiment, data analysis, hypothesis, hypothesis evaluation
observation, question, hypothesis, experiment, hypothesis evaluation, data analysis
question, experiment, hypothesis, observation, hypothesis evaluation, data analysis

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes a hypothesis?

options.text: a prediction about what one expects to observe
the variable to be changed in the experiment
the controlled conditions of the experiment
a broad understanding of a scientific principle
the explanation for an observed phenomenon

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios does NOT follow the scientific method?

options.text: Josie runs her experiment once and uses the results to answer her question.
Destiny uses previous knowledge to develop a hypothesis.
Tonya collects empirical data during her experiment to answer her question.
Samantha uses new knowledge after her experiment to evaluate her hypothesis.
Amanda designs her experiment to be reproducible under identical conditions.

the temperature of the water in each fish tank
the number of fish in each tank
the health of the fish in each tank

options.text: dependent variable
controlled variable
independent variable
discrete variable
hypothetical variable

assestmentData.question: What question does Activity 1 of this investigation seek to answer?

options.text: How fast does an Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet dissolve in water at different temperatures?
How fast does an Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet dissolve in water at different pHs?
How many Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablets can dissolve in 1 L of water?
How does surface area of an Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet affect its time to dissolve?
How does pH affect the efficacy of an Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet as an antacid?

Clean and sanitize work area.
Read the instructions.
Obtain all materials.

In Activity 1, you will attempt to answer the testable question “How fast does an Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet dissolve in water at different temperatures?” You will dissolve one Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet in each of three different water baths – cold, room temperature, and hot – and record the time it takes each table to dissolve completely. This experiment is repeated for a total of three trials. Then, the average temperature and average time for each type of water bath will be calculated.

typeBefore.title: Part I. Setting Up the Experiment
typeBefore.text: Three different temperature baths will be prepared with approximately the same amount of water in each. Ideally, there should be about 50–60°C difference between the cold and hot temperatures.

pageData.text: Label the three cups C (for cold), H (for hot), and RT (for room temperature) using the wax pencil.
Obtain a timing device such as a cell phone or stopwatch.
Make an ice bath by adding ice and at least 300 mL cold water to a bowl or cup.
Open the Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> packages.
With scissors, or a knife, carefully score one side of each Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet into equal halves.
Carefully break each tablet into two pieces.

Tip: To break the Alka-Seltzer® tablets into equal portions, take a sharp knife or scalpel and lightly score a line across the back of the tablet. Repeat this process several times along the same line. Using light pressure, break the tablet in half along the line. If your tablets have been broken in shipping, try to create three equal-sized pieces for one of your trials and note the size variance on your data table.
Use the 250-mL beaker to measure 200 mL of room temperature tap water and pour it in the “RT” cup.
Use the 250-mL beaker to measure 200 mL of hot tap water and pour it in the “H” cup.
Use the 250-mL beaker to measure 200 mL of ice-cold water from the ice water bath (do not include any ice) and pour it in the “C” cup.

typeAfter.text: Use the thermometer to measure the temperature of water in each of the three cups. Record these temperatures in Data table 1.

pageData.text: Carefully drop an Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablet into each cup, starting with the “C” cup, followed by the “RT” cup, and then the “H” cup.
Immediately start the timer.
Observe the Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablets as they begin to dissolve in each cup.
When the last piece of tablet has dissolved, record the time to the nearest second for that cup in Data Table 1 (Run No. 1).
Pour the Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> solution from each cup down the drain, and rinse out the cups with clean water.
The tablet will normally be floating near the top of the water by the end of the reaction.

typeBefore.title: Part III. Repeating the Experiment

pageData.text: Repeat Part II for two additional trials at each temperature. Use exactly 200 mL of water in each cup.
For each temperature range, calculate the average temperature and the average time.

In Activity 2, you will brainstorm 5 new questions about the rate at which Alka-Seltzer<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> tablets dissolve. You will choose one question for which you will develop a <button class='glossary-text'>hypothesis</button>, you will identify the <button class='glossary-text'>variables</button> involved in testing your hypothesis and design an experiment using these variables. Once your experiment has been conducted, you will evaluate your hypothesis based on the data collected.
List five questions about the rate at which Alka-Seltzer® tablets dissolve. Think about the . What would happen if temperature were held constant and one of the controlled was changed?
Develop a new based on one of the questions. Remember that a hypothesis must be testable with empirical, or measurable, data. Fill in Activity 2 Table.

typeBefore.title: Testing the New Hypothesis

pageData.text: To test your hypothesis, design a procedure similar to the test procedure in Activity 1. The test procedure should be described so another person can repeat it exactly as it will be performed here. Be specific and detailed in writing the procedure. Provide a materials list and descriptions of setting up and running the experiment, including a description of how data will be collected. Also describe repeating the experiment to determine reproducibility of the results.
Perform your experiment and record the results in Data Table 2.

pageData.content: Figure 1. The steps of the scientific method

pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. You will start Activity 1 by preparing three water baths with different temperatures. You will prepare the Alka-Seltzer® tablets and record the time in which a tablet dissolves in each bath. After you have completed all three trials, you will calculate the average time and temperature for each bath type. In Activity 2, you develop five questions and hypotheses about how different variables will impact the rate at which Alka-Seltzer® tablets dissolve. You will design and perform the experiments. After you gather the data, you will evaluate your results and your hypotheses.

data.title: Controlled variables
data.content: All other, nonindependent and nondependent variables, and they should remain unchanged while the independent variable is manipulated and the effect on the dependent variable is measured or observed.

data.title: Dependent variables
data.content: Measurable, but their values are dependent on the independent variables.

data.title: Hypothesis
data.content: An educated assumption or prediction of what one expects to observe, or the predicted results of an experiment.

data.title: Independent variable
data.content: The factor hypothesized to produce the effect under investigation.

data.title: Science
data.content: An evidence-based discipline that attempts to build a better understanding of the natural world and how it works.

data.title: Scientific method
data.content: One of the primary tools of scientific research used to answer specific questions.

data.title: Variables
data.content: Factors relevant to the question being asked.
